data.title: Terminal: adopt multiple root folders for link detection
data.body:
While going through places where we still use the old workspace interface with single root I noticed that the integrated terminal uses the root path to detect relative links: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalLinkHandler.ts#L197

Can we change this to use the `cwd` the terminal was created with instead? That seems to be like a good hint to decide against which folder to resolve to. Or, maybe we should resolve it to the folder the command was executed from.

data.title: TypeScript SDK from workspace settings seems to be ignored
data.body:
Hello everyone,

I started recently to VSCode in favor of Atom and I have to say nice work, I like it: it is slim and fast. However I've created a new project with TypeScript where I would like to use the specified version from my `package.json`. So what I did is the following:

Created a new file named `settings.json` inside the `.vscode` directory which lives in the project root. The current content of this file is:
```json
// This are workspace specific settings.
{
  // General settings.
  "files.exclude": {
    "**/.git": true,
    "**/.DS_Store": true
  },
  // TypeScript settings.
  "typescript.tsdk": "./node_modules/typescript/lib",
  "typescript.check.tscVersion": false
}
```

My expectation would be to see in the status bar that I am using the version (2.4.0) of TypeScript which I've installed. By default it seems to be selecting the default shipped(?) version I guess, not sure where exactly it comes from. As I said, I am new to VSCode (;

If I remove the `typescript.check.tscVersion` options from the settings it will at least ask me which version to use. It is fine for me, but since the project is kind of a boilerplate it might be confusing for others. Yes, I know that you have a nice document describing it but I thought that why you added a setting for it, no?

- OS Version: Mac OS 10.12.5
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1 (1.13.1)
- Extensions:
  * EditorConfig.EditorConfig
  * HookyQR.beautify
  * PeterJausovec.vscode-docker
  * WallabyJs.wallaby-vscode
  * eamodio.gitlens

Steps to Reproduce:
```sh
mkdir -p vscode-workspace-settings/.vscode
cd vscode-workspace-settings
echo '{"typescript.tsdk": "./node_modules/typescript/lib","typescript.check.tscVersion": false}' > .vscode/settings.json
echo "console.log('Hello you!')" > hello.ts
npm init -y
npm install --save-dev typescript@2.4.0
code hello.ts
```

data.title: Got a 'bug' in language configuration.
data.body:
**VSCode Version:** 1.13.1;
**Platform:** win10;

I tried to set the language of vscode as Chinese, so I opened the language configuration and modified the value from 'en' to 'zh'. Then I reloaded the vscode, it didn't work, even can't open the app window, but created a progress in system.
Absolutely I didn't wrong thing in set, **Chinese setting should corresponding to 'zh-cn', I did 'zh'**, so the app ran with error.  
Then I created a issue here and got a way to resolve from @kongyuan that just delete the folder 'Code/User', finally I found the problem at 'locale' file there. Three days to resolve this! What a fool am I...
But I think a invalid language value setting should not cause a breakdown, may giving some tips to tell users how to set the value correctly is better.
So I suggest if some improvement should be made there. 
**I love vscode!** 
Hope it get better and better!

data.title: Syntax coloring is broken when writing PHP in <script>
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.5|
|php-debug|felixfbecker|1.10.0|
|php-intellisense|felixfbecker|1.4.1|
|php-pack|felixfbecker|1.0.1|
|jinja|wholroyd|0.0.8|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

Open the following sample code with VSCode.

```php
<?php
    define('JSON_OPT', \JSON_HEX_TAG | \JSON_HEX_AMP | \JSON_HEX_APOS | \JSON_HEX_QUOT);
    $name = $_GET['name'] ?? "Nemo";
?>
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>
    <script>
        var name = <?= json_encode($name, JSON_OPT) ?>;
        alert('Hello, ' + name + '!');
    </script>
</body>
</html>
```

![PHP code in script tag](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11690370/27269920-a5b75e48-54f5-11e7-8bfa-21a58614a38a.png)

After writing PHP codes in `<script>`, color of HTML tags change.
Is there a way to avoid something?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a build task called "Build" in tasks.json
2. Create a launch configuration in launch.json
3. set the "preLaunchTask": "Build"
4. Launch with F5 and the build task will fire.
5. Press Ctrl+Shift+F5 to restart the debugging session. the build does not fire first.
Maybe we need a "preRestartTask"

data.title: [json] show title in hover as well
data.body:
I'm developing a VS Code extension which contributes a jsonValidation.  The schema is derived from a Swagger specification, which uses 'title' for the short-form summary of a property and 'description' for more expansive detail.  This is per [JSON Schema recommendations](http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-validation.html#rfc.section.7.2), and specifically to work with AutoRest which uses the title to generate C# `/// <summary>` documentation and the description to generate `/// <remarks>` documentation.

When I reference this schema in VS Code, if I have a JSON property which has both a title and a description in the schema, the tooltip for that property is the _description_, not the title.  If I have a JSON property which has a title but no description, no tooltip is shown for that property.  In my extension this leads to awkward remarks-level detail in tooltips, or to no documentation at all.

It would be useful if the tooltip could show the title (if present) in preference to the description, or to show the title as well as the description.

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. See sample repo https://github.com/itowlson/vscode-json-schema-test and load the extension.  Note the contents of `schema/foo.schema.json`.
2. Run this extension in the Extension Development Host (or create a new extension and add the `jsonValidation` section and `foo.schema.json` file from the sample repo).
3. In the Extension Development Host, open the file `test/test.foo.json`.
4. Hover over the `"id"` element.  **Expected:** Tooltip showing "A unique ID."  **Actual:** Tooltip showing "May be up to 64 characters."
5. Hover over the "displayName" element.  **Expected:** Tooltip showing "A name for use in a UI.."  **Actual:** Nothing happens.

---
